journal-meta.journal-title: The American Journal of Sports Medicine

title-group.article-title: Results of Arthroscopic Repair of Partial- or Full-Thickness Longitudinal Medial Meniscal Tears by Single or Double Vertical Sutures Using the Inside-Out Technique

article-meta.aff: †Department of Orthopedics and Traumatology, Acibadem Kadikoy Hospital, Istanbul, Turkey
‡Department of Orthopedics and Traumatology, Kastamonu Tosya Hospital, Kastamonu, Turkey
§Department of Orthopedics and Traumatology, Haydarpasa Numune Training and Research Hospital, Uskudar/Istanbul, Turkey
Investigation performed at the Department of Orthopedics and Traumatology, Acibadem Kadikoy Hospital, Istanbul, Turkey

author-notes.corresp: *Ugur Haklar, MD, Department of Orthopedics and Traumatology, Acibadem Kadikoy Hospital, Tekin Sokak No. 8 Kadikoy 34718 Istanbul, Turkey (e-mail: dr.haklar@superonline.com).

permissions.copyright-holder: American Orthopaedic Society for Sports Medicine

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: Although numerous studies have assessed arthroscopic repair of meniscal tears, no study has described the repair of partial- or full-thickness longitudinal medial meniscal tears using single or double vertical sutures.

sec.title: Purpose:
sec.p: To present the intermediate-term results of medial meniscal tears repaired with single or double vertical sutures.

sec.title: Study Design:
sec.p: Case series; Level of evidence, 4.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: The authors evaluated the results of 112 longitudinal medial meniscal tears treated with inside-out single or double vertical sutures, with or without anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) reconstruction, based on the clinical resolution of symptoms, the Lysholm knee scoring scale, and the Tegner activity scale. Re-examination was also performed by magnetic resonance imaging after the repair. The length of the tears was evaluated arthroscopically. Eighty-five tears of 112 were >2 cm in length, and 27 were tears ≤2 cm. Eighty-nine (79.4%) of the 112 repairs were performed in conjunction with ACL reconstructions, and the remaining 23 (20.6%) repairs were performed in ACL-intact knees. The tear type of the menisci in our study was full thickness in 66 (58.9%) cases and partial thickness in 46 (41.1%) cases. Double vertical sutures were used for full-thickness tears, and single vertical sutures were used for partial-thickness tears.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: The cases were evaluated after a mean follow-up duration of 49.3 months (range, 12-88 months). Clinical and radiological examination results determined that 99 (88.4%) meniscal repairs had healed, and the remaining 13 cases (10.6%) were considered to be failures. The healing rate of the full-thickness group was 80.3%, while in the partial-thickness group, the rate was 100%. The mean Lysholm score improved significantly from a preoperative value of 63.8 to a postoperative value of 89.5 (P < .001). The mean Tegner activity score was 3.3 preoperatively and 6.7 postoperatively (P < .001). Logistic regression analysis found that concurrent ACL reconstruction, tear length, and smoking as factors had a significant effect on meniscal healing.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: Single or double vertical sutures using the inside-out technique provide a high rate of healing in longitudinal medial meniscal tears.

body.p: Meniscal tissue is essential for load transmission, shock absorption, joint stability, and joint lubrication of the knee.4 Total or partial removal of meniscal tissue causes subsequent degeneration of the articular cartilage over time.31 Therefore, it is imperative to preserve the meniscal tissue.

It is well known that some differences exist between the medial and lateral meniscus in terms of their anatomic and functional properties. The lateral meniscus is mainly circular, whereas the medial meniscus is semilunar (C-shaped). The medial meniscus is also firmly attached to the posterior portion of the tibia, but the anterior attachment can be less stable. In addition, the medial meniscus has a continuous peripheral attachment, but the lateral meniscus is not attached to this region of the popliteal hiatus or the collateral ligament. Despite these attachments, the menisci display a certain degree of mobility, and the relative greater mobility of the lateral meniscus can reduce the risk of breakage.4 In addition, it has been demonstrated that the medial meniscus functions as a secondary restraint in the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL)–deficient knee.37

There are 2 arthroscopic classification methods for meniscal tears. The first is based on the position with reference to vascular zones (red-red, red-white, or white-white zones), and the second is based on the orientation and appearance of the type of lesion (longitudinal, horizontal, radial, or complex tears).4

Previous studies have demonstrated that the configuration of the stitch is more important than the system used for the repair.11 A vertical suture pattern is preferred in our study because this pattern has the highest pull-out strength and has superior failure strength.4,5,29,37 Double vertical sutures were used for full-thickness tears, and single vertical sutures were used for partial-thickness tears.

Meniscal tears are one of the most common orthopaedic problems that can occur. Therefore, orthopaedic surgeons prefer to understand the likelihood of healing after the repair as well as the factors that can affect healing. Although numerous articles regarding meniscal repairs and the results achieved with different techniques and devices exist in the literature, there are no reports describing repair of longitudinal medial meniscal tears using single or double vertical sutures. Therefore, this study describes the clinical results of inside-out meniscal repairs in full- or partial-thickness longitudinal medial meniscal tears, with or without ACL reconstruction, using single or double vertical sutures and a zone-specific curved cannula. To maintain the objectivity of the results, we only included patients with medial meniscal tears in our study.

The objectives of this study were to evaluate the clinical results of a meniscal repair system using single or double vertical sutures and examine factors that could affect the healing rate, such as patient age, chronicity of tear (time from injury to repair), length of tear, patient smoking habits, type of tear, suture material used (No. 2 or No. 0 Ethibond), and concurrent ACL reconstruction at the time of meniscal repair.

sec.title: Patients and Procedures
sec.p: From May 2005 to March 2011, the senior author (U.H.) performed 140 arthroscopic meniscal repairs in 140 patients. All 140 menisci were medial. In our hospital, we also repair lateral meniscal tears, but to maintain the objectivity of the results, we only included longitudinal medial meniscal tears located in the red-red or red-white zones of the menisci. If the meniscal tear also had a radial or horizontal component, it was trimmed before the meniscal repair. An ACL deficiency was present in 99 of the 140 cases. Ninety-nine (70.7%) of the 140 repairs were performed in conjunction with ACL reconstructions; the remaining 41 repairs (29.3%) were performed in knees with intact ACLs.

Medial meniscal tears were diagnosed in all patients based on the symptoms, physical examination, and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) results. We informed patients of their options and received written informed consent for arthroscopic surgery from all participants in the study. The ethics committee of our university hospital approved this study.
The repair was performed with or without ACL reconstruction using single or double vertical sutures with the inside-out technique and zone-specific curved cannulas.

sec.title: Technique
sec.p: Surgery was performed under general or regional anesthesia. We used a tourniquet to enhance visualization during the operation by placing it as high as possible on the proximal aspect of the thigh. Routine anteromedial and anterolateral arthroscopic portals were used. We probed the meniscal tear to see if the tear was in the red-white or red-red zone of the meniscus.

During the arthroscopic procedure, we separated the longitudinal meniscal tears into partial-thickness (group I) tears and full-thickness (group II) tears based on the tear type. We then divided the partial-thickness group further into those in which the tear extended into only the superior articular surface (group Ia) or those in which the tear extended into the inferior articular surface (group Ib). The full-thickness group was further divided into those in which the tear extended into both the inferior and superior surfaces (group IIa) or those in which there was a displaced tear (group IIb). If there was a displaced bucket-handle tear, a reduction was first performed (Figure 1).

caption.p: Demonstrations of longitudinal meniscal tears. The tears extending into only the superior articular surface (A), only the inferior articular surface (B), and into both the superior and inferior articular surfaces (C).

sec.p: We prepared the meniscal tear edges if a repair was to be performed. The preparation included debriding unhealthy tissue at the edges of the tear to increase the vascularity at the repair site by using either a meniscal rasp or mechanical shaver. To begin the repair, we first optimally reduced the meniscal tear. If the tear was full thickness, we used double vertical sutures. Superior sutures were placed first, followed by inferior sutures using a Zone Specific II Meniscal Repair System (Linvatec, Largo, Florida) device (Figure 1). For partial-thickness tears, single vertical sutures were used. Superior sutures were placed if the tear extended into the superior articular surface only, and inferior sutures were used if the tear extended into the inferior articular surface only. We repeated this process and placed stitches every 6 to 7 mm along the length of the tear. At the end of the procedure, we counted the sutures used for repair, which provided an approximation of the tear size. A 4- to 6-cm skin incision was created immediately proximal to the sutures and posterior to the medial collateral ligament, and then dissection was performed to expose the joint capsule. The sutures that came through or posterior to the semimembranosus tendon were placed anterior to the tendon. The sutures were then tightened from posterior to anterior and tied over the capsule. While the posterior sutures were being tied, the knee was flexed 45° to 60°, and while the anterior sutures were being tied, the knee was flexed 0° to 20°. This technique was chosen as it is impossible to tie sutures while the knee is in extension because of the hamstring tendons. After the repair was completed, the tear was probed to assess the stability of the stitches.

If the patient had an ACL deficiency, we performed the meniscal repair concurrent with the ACL reconstruction. In these cases, the autologous semitendinosus and gracilis tendons were first harvested, which was required for reconstruction, and then the following steps were performed in order: the meniscal sutures were passed, the femoral and tibial tunnels were drilled, the ACL graft was placed in the tunnels, the meniscal sutures were tied, and tibial fixation of the ACL was accomplished. In procedures performed since February 2008 in patients without an ACL deficiency, we created 5 to 8 multiple perforations with microfracture awls in the nonloadbearing region (approximately 3 cm2) of the medial femoral condyle, which was located on the medial wall of the femoral condyle and 1.5 to 2 cm proximal to the joint space, followed by excision of the synovia around the perforations (Figure 2). This approach produced vascular channels and promoted the migration of multipotent cells to the repair side to stimulate meniscal healing.

caption.p: Fluoroscopic (A) and arthroscopic (B) views of microfracture.

sec.title: Follow-up
sec.p: A postoperative rehabilitation program was used for all patients. For the first 0 to 4 weeks after surgery, the patients were allowed 0° to 90° of flexion. From 4 weeks to 4 months after surgery, the patients were allowed the maximal flexion that they could tolerate, and after 4 months, terminal flexion was permitted. Patients with partial- and full-thickness longitudinal tears were allowed to bear weight at 3 and 4 to 5 weeks after surgery, respectively.

We evaluated our results based on clinical symptoms, including swelling, joint line tenderness, locking or blocking, and the McMurray test.23 Radiological examination was also performed, which included an assessment of the repaired meniscus by MRI at 6 months after the repair and at the last follow-up based on T2 coronal, sagittal, and axial views (Figure 3). If the patient had 3 or more clinical symptoms and/or grade 3 signals on T2 sequences on the MRI, the meniscus was considered to be unhealed. If the patient had a positive McMurray test result, tenderness on joint line palpation, and/or a view of fluid within the repair site by MRI, the repair was considered a failure. We also evaluated patients using the Lysholm knee scoring scale and Tegner activity scale.33

caption.p: Sagittal (A), coronal (B), and axial (C) T2 sequences on magnetic resonance imaging of a case, indicating full healing without residual signal hyperintensity at 26 months after surgery.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Statistical analysis was performed using the χ2 test, Fisher exact test for univariate analysis, logistic regression analysis for multivariate analysis, and power analysis. P values <.05 were considered statistically significant. We planned a study with 112 patients using a power of .928 on the basis of prior data, indicating that the probability of a treatment failure in the control group was .10. The type I error associated with the null hypothesis test was .05.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Twenty-eight of 140 patients were lost to follow-up, and therefore, 112 patients (112 menisci; 80%) were used for this analysis. Ninety-four men (83%) and 18 women (17%) were included in the study. The patients’ average age at the time of meniscal repair was 34.57 ± 8.85 years (range, 16-53 years). All patients were followed up for an average of 48.39 ± 20.25 months (range, 12-88 months) (Table 1). The follow-up duration ranged from 12 to 24 months for 13 patients (11.6%). The average time that passed from the date of injury to the date of operation was 122.62 ± 175.69 days (range, 0-782 days). There were 23 (21%) isolated meniscal repairs and 89 (79%) meniscal repairs in conjunction with ACL reconstruction.

tr.td: Chronicity (time from injury to repair), d

sec.p: The length of the tears was evaluated arthroscopically. Eighty-five patients had a tear that was more than 2 cm in length, and 27 patients had a tear that was 2 cm or less. The average length of the tears was 31.46 ± 11.74 mm (range, 13-58 mm). Ethibond No. 2 sutures (Ethicon, Somerville, New Jersey) were used in 32 patients, and Ethibond No. 0 sutures (Ethicon) were used in 80 patients.

At the last follow-up, physical examination and MRI were performed for all patients. Based on assessment, 99 (88.4%) meniscal repairs had healed. The remaining 13 cases (11.6%) were considered to be failures. Three of the failures were caused by infection and were treated with arthroscopic partial meniscectomy, debridement, and antibiotic therapy. In these cases, the infection was localized around the suture knots just outside the joint capsule. Partial meniscectomy was recommended in the remaining 10 cases; it was performed in 9 cases, and 1 patient did not accept another surgery.

The type of meniscal tears only included longitudinal tears. Sixty-six (58.9%) were full-thickness tears, and 46 were partial-thickness tears (41.1%). The healing rate of the full-thickness group was 80.3%, while the healing rate of the partial-thickness group was 100% (P = .001).

The Lysholm score of patients significantly improved between preoperative assessment and final follow-up (mean, 60.2 [range, 48-72] vs 91.5 [range, 85-98], respectively; P < .001). In addition, the mean Tegner activity score was 3.3 (range, 2-5) at the preoperative assessment compared with a postoperative mean score of 6.7 (range, 5-10) (P < .001).

sec.title: Factors Affecting Meniscal Healing
sec.p: In 10 of 23 isolated meniscal tears, microfractures were introduced in the nonloadbearing region of the medial femoral condyle, and all 10 cases healed (100%). Eight of the remaining 13 cases also healed (61.5%) (Table 2). The introduction of additional microfractures to isolated meniscal tears had a significant effect on healing (P = .038). Among patients with isolated meniscal tears (n = 23), the length of tear, smoking status, and suture type had no significant effect on healing (P > .05) (Table 3). Based on univariate analysis including all patients (n = 112), concurrent ACL reconstruction at the time of meniscal repair, type of tear (full or partial thickness), length of tear, and smoking significantly affected meniscal healing (P < .05) (Table 4).

caption.p: Factors Affecting the Healing of Repaired Meniscus in Patients With Isolated Meniscal Tears
Factors Affecting the Healing of Repaired Meniscus

sec.p: The following variables were included in the multivariate analysis: age, chronicity, length of tear, ACL reconstruction, smoking, and suture material. Based on multivariate analysis, concurrent ACL reconstruction at the time of meniscal repair, length of tear, and smoking significantly affected meniscal healing (P < .05) (Table 5).

caption.p: Logistic Regression Analysis Factors Affecting the Healing of Repaired Meniscusa

fn.label: a
fn.p: Type of tear was not included in this analysis, as all partial-type tears were healed.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: A greater understanding of the importance of meniscal tissue has improved in recent times, and for the past 10 years, meniscectomy was a common method of treatment, performed in meniscal tears.24 However, studies have postulated that subtotal or partial meniscectomies can lead to the early onset of knee osteoarthritis.32 Recently, meniscal implants and meniscal transplantation have been popularized in meniscus-deficient knees,2,6,7 but these methods are only options if there is a meniscal loss. Therefore, the first surgical choice is to repair a torn meniscus, if possible, because although meniscal repairs have a higher reoperation rate than partial meniscectomies, they are associated with better long-term outcomes.27

Second-look arthroscopic surgery is the gold standard in assessing the healing status of repaired menisci. Ahn et al1 performed second-look arthroscopic surgery on 38 clinically asymptomatic patients and only found 1 failure. Miao et al23 also compared the diagnostic value of second-look arthroscopic surgery, clinical assessment, and MRI for evaluating meniscal healing status after meniscal repair. They found that with the presence of 3 or more clinical symptoms, it is possible to diagnose unhealed menisci. In addition, the authors found that the T2 sequence on MRI shows higher specificity and accuracy in assessing the healing status of repaired menisci than other views. In our study, we did not perform second-look arthroscopic surgery to evaluate the healing status of the meniscus because of ethical considerations, and therefore, arthroscopic surgery was not performed if it was not indicated. Our follow-up examination consisted of clinical and radiological assessments of the repaired menisci. We had 10 patients with failure according to our criteria and performed second-look arthroscopic surgery in 9 of these patients. The second-look arthroscopic procedure confirmed that all 9 patients had repair failure. Therefore, based on our findings as well as previous studies,1,23 we believe that our clinical and radiological examination criteria are reliable methods for evaluating menisci after repair.

Previous studies have demonstrated that a vertical suture pattern has the highest pull-out strength and superior load-to-failure strength.4,5,29,38 Kocabey et al16 compared the pull-out strength of vertical, horizontal, and oblique suture techniques after cyclic loading. They reported that the load at failure using oblique sutures (171.9 ± 25.9 N) was not significantly different than that with vertical sutures (145.9 ± 32.3 N) and that both were superior to horizontal sutures (88.8 ± 8.2 N). According to Rimmer et al,30 vertical sutures are perpendicular to the alignment of the collagen fibers of the menisci. Similar to fractures, reduction is also important in meniscal tears, and therefore, torn menisci should be reduced and stabilized anatomically. We used vertical sutures during our study instead of oblique or horizontal sutures. Ahn et al1 found that in medial meniscal posterior horn tears, it is difficult to create vertical sutures with inside-out and outside-in techniques, and as a result, neurovascular structures may be at risk. In our study, even if the medial meniscal tears were localized to the posterior horn, we were able to pass the vertical sutures using zone-specific cannulas without damaging the neurovascular structures and joint cartilage.

Paxton et al27 reviewed the literature and reported an inside-out technique failure rate of 18%. In addition, they found that the overall reoperation rate after meniscal repair was 24% compared with 14% when the repair was performed in conjunction with ACL reconstruction. Stein et al32 reported a healing rate of 86%, while Kimura et al14 reported a healing rate of 84% with the inside-out suturing technique. To maintain objectivity, our study was restricted to only longitudinal medial meniscal tears. It is well known that the anatomic features, mechanical properties, and blood supply patterns of the medial and lateral menisci are different. The lateral meniscus is more mobile than the medial meniscus, which is why the medial meniscus receives greater biomechanical loads.36 In addition, repair of the medial meniscus has a higher reoperation rate than repair of the lateral meniscus.27 Therefore, we should have obtained lower healing rates than the average described in the literature. For these reasons, the results of lateral and medial meniscal repairs should not be evaluated together. Majewski et al20 repaired isolated longitudinal, vertical tears in medial and lateral menisci and observed a failure rate of 24%. In our present study, we achieved an overall healing rate of 88.4%, which increased to 91% if the procedure was performed concomitantly with ACL reconstruction. These rates are slightly better than the respective results in the literature. In our opinion, the most effective factor for achieving better healing rates is our inside-out single or double vertical suturing technique. However, to confirm the superiority of our inside-out suturing technique, our results need to be compared with the results of different suturing techniques in medial meniscal repairs. Because this was not possible, it may be a limitation of our study.

Studies have demonstrated that concomitant ACL reconstruction during meniscal repair improves the outcomes of the repair.9,17,21 Barrett et al3 observed a clinical failure rate of 27% after the repair of isolated meniscal tears compared with a failure rate of 4.5% after combined ACL reconstruction and meniscal repair. This may be related to the multipotent cells and growth factors migrating from the bone marrow. Therefore, some studies have suggested that isolated meniscal tears should be repaired with meniscal rasping,25 fibrin clots,13,35 trephination,40 rasping parameniscal synovia,26 or microfracture in the notch.8 In our study, we performed 23 isolated meniscal repairs, and multiple perforations using a microfracture awl in the medial side of the medial femoral condyle were made in 10 cases. Although previous studies have suggested that microfractures should be made in the intercondylar notch,5,8 we selected the medial side of the medial femoral condyle for the microfractures. This decision was based on our hypothesis that multipotent cells spreading into the intercondylar region after microfracture will scatter in the knee joint but will fall off the medial side of the medial femoral condyle into the repair site, thereby reaching this region more easily. All 10 of these menisci (100%) healed, and 8 of the remaining 13 cases also healed (61.5%). Although the number of cases in our study was low, based on the high success rate, we believe that performing microfractures in isolated meniscal repairs is a method that can improve the healing rate of meniscal tears.

During the arthroscopic procedure, we classified meniscal tears into 2 categories: full-thickness tears and partial-thickness tears. The healing rate of the full-thickness group was 80.3%, while in the partial-thickness group, the rate was 100%. Based on these results, we found that the type of the tear was a significant factor in meniscal healing.

According to some previous studies in the literature, smoking is a factor that can negatively influence soft tissue healing.10,39 However, no study to date has specifically assessed the effects of smoking on meniscal healing. Based on our results, we confirmed that smoking has a negative effect on meniscal healing.

The tear length of the menisci in our study was greater than 20 mm in 85 cases and less than 20 mm in 27 cases. The healing rates in these groups were 87% and 92.6%, respectively. We found that if the tear length was greater than 2 cm, it was a significant factor in meniscal healing, which is in contrast to the results of Kotsovolos et al18 previously described. In addition, Kocabey et al15 found that a larger diameter of a suture can increase the pull-out strength and that No. 2 sutures are mechanically superior to No. 0 or No. 1 braided sutures. However, in our study, we did not observe any difference between No. 2 and No. 0 sutures.

The chronicity of injury and age of the patient are believed to influence the potential for meniscal repair, with poorer results being observed in cases with a significant time lapse after injury as well as older patients.34 We did not observe any difference in the rate of meniscal healing between the cases that were repaired within 6 weeks and those repaired after 6 weeks, similar to the study by Melton et al.22 Our study also did not find chronicity to be a significant factor for the healing rate, similar to other studies.12,28 This may be because we abraded the unhealthy tissue in the tear edges of the torn menisci in all cases. However, we hypothesize that partial tears may turn into complete tears over time, which may be a factor that reduces meniscal healing.

Patient age (being younger or older than 30 years) was not found to be a significant factor for the success in meniscal repairs in our study. Our results are in agreement with those of other investigators who found no significant difference between younger and older age groups in meniscal healing.12,19

In conclusion, we found that arthroscopic inside-out vertical sutures using zone-specific cannulas provided successful clinical outcomes in longitudinal medial meniscal tears with a healing rate of 88.4%. The healing rate of the full-thickness group was 80.3%, while in the partial-thickness group, the rate was 100%. In addition, we found that concurrent ACL reconstruction, type of tear, tear length, and smoking significantly affected meniscal healing. However, future studies are needed to determine other factors that may affect the healing rate of repaired menisci.

fn.p: The authors declared that they have no conflicts of interest in the authorship and publication of this contribution.
